social_posts.post_text:
Hi, Everyone! We are Eric and Christopher from GrowForMeGardening (formerly GrowForMe5b), your go-to guys for gardening in Zone 5b/6a Upstate New York! We have a contemporary cottage garden aesthetic and a stunning collection of over 140 hydrangeas and 50 roses! We pride ourselves on having mastered the art of starting a new garden from the ground up. Join us as we cultivate beauty, flowers, and fun in our garden. 
Please introduce yourselves below! Let us know what zone you garden in and what gardening means to you! 🙌🏼🙌🏼🥰🥰

Hey everyone! Come and see our garden! Click follow and join us on our gardening journey. 
We are a small half acre garden that was built from scratch in a new construction neighborhood. 
Our garden has over 140 hydrangeas and more than 50 roses! We love a contemporary cottage style and excel at creating beautiful vignettes to share! 
We look forward to meeting you.  Zone 5b, NY

#garden #gardening #gardendesign #gardenrecipe #gardenersquestiontime #gardenbloggers #gardeninggeek #gardenjoy #gardeninspiration #gardenlove #gardendecor #gardenhome #growforme5b

5 simple tips for your garden below:

	1.	Start with Easy-to-Grow Plants: Begin your gardening journey with plants that are known for their resilience and ease of care. @provenwinners and @pwcolorchoice are a great place to start! Also, herbs like basil, mint (in a pot only), or sturdy flowers like marigolds are great choices for beginners.
	2.	Proper Watering: Stick to a consistent watering schedule, giving your plants the right amount of water without overdoing it. Consider using a watering can to control the flow and avoid waterlogged soil. Check out our YouTube for how we set up drip irrigation!
	3.	Mulching: Apply a layer of mulch around your plants to help retain moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature. This simple step contributes to overall plant health and reduces the need for frequent watering. We use compost as mulch in our garden. 
	4.	Regular Pruning: Keep your plants in good shape by regularly removing dead or yellowing leaves. Pruning encourages healthy growth and can help prevent the spread of diseases.
	5.	Sunlight Awareness: Understand the sunlight needs of your plants. Place sun-loving plants in areas that receive ample sunlight, while shade-tolerant plants should be positioned in areas with less direct sun exposure. Observing and adapting to your garden’s microclimates makes a significant impact.

Make sure to click follow and join us for more tips and garden inspiration! 🥰🙌🏼🙌🏼

If you LOVE hydrangeas, you’ve come to the right place! We have over 140 hydrangeas in our half acre garden, and we’re POSITIVE we won’t be stopping there! 
From Panicles to Annabelles, Oakleafs, and Big Leafs, we grow a huge variety in our zone 5b/6a garden. 
Click follow and join us to learn more about hydrangeas and be inspired by all that you can do with them in your garden. 
The most common types are:
	1.	Bigleaf Hydrangea (Hydrangea macrophylla):
	•	Known for their large, showy blooms.
	•	Divided into two main types: Mophead (round, globe-like flowers) and Lacecap (flat-topped flowers with a central cluster of tiny fertile florets surrounded by larger sterile florets).
	2.	Panicle Hydrangea (Hydrangea paniculata):
	•	Cone-shaped flower clusters that can be quite large.
	•	Typically more tolerant of sun and can handle a wider range of growing conditions.
	•	Varieties include ‘Limelight’ and ‘PeeGee.’
	3.	Smooth Hydrangea (Hydrangea arborescens):
	•	Features large, round flower clusters.
	•	Notable variety is the ‘Annabelle,’ known for its white, globe-shaped blooms.
	4.	Oakleaf Hydrangea (Hydrangea quercifolia):
	•	Named for its lobed leaves resembling those of an oak tree.
	•	Conical flower clusters and vibrant fall foliage add to its appeal.
	5.	Climbing Hydrangea (Hydrangea anomala petiolaris):
	•	Adaptable climbing variety that can scale walls or structures.
	•	Characterized by white, flat-topped clusters of flowers.
	6.	Mountain Hydrangea (Hydrangea serrata):
	•	Similar to Bigleaf Hydrangea but generally smaller.
	•	Often prized for their delicate lacecap blooms.
#hydrangea #hydrangeas #hydrangeasaremyfavorite #growformegardening #growforme5b #hydrangeagarden

All jokes aside, January is a great time to rest, recover, and dream about the upcoming gardening season. 
Although we truly miss being out in the garden everyday, resting and resetting is an important part of being a gardener. Here’s why embracing rest is a crucial part of your gardening journey:

	1.	Nature’s Rhythms: Gardens follow the ebb and flow of seasons, and so should we. Embrace the dormant winter, allowing both your garden and yourself a well-deserved break. It’s a chance to recharge for the blooming chaos that spring brings.
	2.	Mindful Observations: Rest provides a unique opportunity to observe your garden without the distractions of active care. Witness subtle changes, plan for future improvements, and truly connect with the evolving beauty around you.
	3.	Body Rejuvenation: Gardening can be a physically demanding activity. Take time to rest those green thumbs, stretch, and rejuvenate. Your body will thank you, and you’ll return to your garden with newfound energy.
	4.	Creative Resurgence: Restful moments are often when creativity flourishes. Dream up new garden layouts, imagine vibrant color schemes, and plan projects that will bring fresh life to your outdoor sanctuary.
	5.	Seasonal Reflections: Use the downtime to reflect on the past growing season. Celebrate successes, learn from challenges, and set intentions for the upcoming year. A rested mind is more receptive to thoughtful planning.
	6.	Environmental Harmony: Gardens thrive when there’s a balance between activity and stillness. Allow your garden to breathe, undisturbed by constant intervention. Let nature play its part in maintaining harmony. 

#rest #relax #gardenrest #winterrest #garden #gardening #growformegardening #growforme5b #gardentips #gardentipsandtricks #gardeninspiration #gardendesign #gardensofinstagram🌿🌱🌻 #wintergardening #winter #january #januarygarden

Click follow and join us for more gardening ideas and tips! 

1. **Early Spring Beauty:** Daffodils are among the first flowers to bloom in spring, introducing vibrant colors and a sense of renewal to your garden after the winter months.

2. **Low Maintenance:** Daffodils are hardy and require minimal care. Once planted, they thrive with basic attention, making them a hassle-free addition to your garden.

3. **Deer Resistant:** These flowers are generally resistant to deer and other common garden pests, offering a practical solution to protect your garden from unwanted nibbling.

4. **Naturalize and Multiply:** Daffodils have the ability to naturalize, meaning they multiply and come back year after year, gradually forming beautiful clusters that enhance the visual appeal of your garden.

5. **Versatile Varieties:** Daffodils come in various shapes, sizes, and colors. Whether you prefer classic yellow trumpet varieties or unique bi-colored options, you can find daffodils to suit your garden’s aesthetic preferences, adding versatility to your landscape design.

#daffodils #daffodil #daffodils🌼#springflowers #springintoplants #spring #springvibes #gardenideas #gardeninspiration #gardeninspo #gardendesign #gardensofinstagram #growformegardening #zone5b #zone6a #dreamgarden

In the vibrant tapestry of your garden, choosing curiosity over fear can unlock a world of growth and beauty. Just as a gardener eagerly explores new plant varieties and techniques, approaching life’s challenges with a curious mindset can transform our personal landscapes. Instead of fearing the unknown, we embrace it, allowing our lives to bloom with resilience, adaptability, and a deeper connection to the evolving journey. Let curiosity be the guiding force in your garden of life, cultivating a story rich with diverse experiences and vibrant moments. 
Be brave in the garden, have fun, and be curious with us! Follow along and join us on our journey!

We’re thrilled to have you here. May your journey through our feed bring you moments of peace and relaxation as you immerse yourself in the beauty of our flowers and gardens. 
How gardening can bring you calm:
	1.	Nature’s Serenity: Gardens offer a tranquil escape, surrounded by the calming sights and sounds of nature. The rustling leaves, chirping birds, and gentle breeze create a peaceful atmosphere.
	2.	Therapeutic Benefits: Gardening itself is therapeutic. The act of tending to plants, feeling the soil, and witnessing growth promotes mindfulness, reducing stress and fostering a sense of calm.
	3.	Visual Harmony: The harmonious arrangement of colors, textures, and shapes in a garden provides a visually soothing experience. Nature’s symmetry and balance contribute to a sense of peace.
	4.	Fresh Air and Fragrance: Gardens are a source of clean, fresh air. The scent of blooming flowers and aromatic herbs adds a delightful fragrance, enhancing the overall calming effect.
	5.	Escape from Technology: Gardens offer a retreat from the constant buzz of technology. Disconnecting from screens and immersing oneself in the simplicity of a garden promotes mental clarity and relaxation.

#garden #growformegardening #gardening #gardeninglife #mindful #mindfulness #mindfulmoments #calm #calmness #calmyourmind #relax #relaxandenjoy #gardeninspiration

You can do this! We can help! Embarking on a gardening journey is a delightful and life changing endeavor! Begin by selecting a small area, maybe a few pots or a corner in your backyard. Choose easy-to-grow plants and gradually expand your garden as you gain confidence. Patience is key – watch your plants flourish, and enjoy the rewarding process of nurturing nature. Here are 5 tips to help you get started:
	1.	Choose Your Space: Select a sunny spot with well-draining soil. Whether it’s a small balcony, backyard, or windowsill, ensure your chosen area receives adequate sunlight.
	2.	Select Plants Wisely: Opt for beginner-friendly plants like herbs, tomatoes, or flowers. Consider your region’s climate and choose plants that thrive in your specific conditions.
	3.	Prepare the Soil: Invest time in preparing the soil by removing debris, loosening it, and adding compost for nutrients. Healthy soil is the foundation for a thriving garden.
	4.	Watering Routine: Establish a consistent watering schedule. Different plants have varying water needs, so tailor your routine accordingly. Overwatering can be as detrimental as underwatering.
	5.	Start Small, Expand Gradually: Begin with a manageable area or a few pots. As you gain experience and confidence, gradually expand your garden. This approach allows you to learn and enjoy the process without feeling overwhelmed.
#gardentips #gardentipsandtricks #gardentipsforbeginners #gardening #gardeninglove #gardeningismytherapy #gardening101 #gardeningtime #growformegardening #growforme5b #zone6a #zone5b

Maintaining a garden requires time and effort, from weeding to watering. Yet, the joy of watching your plants thrive and the satisfaction of a flourishing garden make it all worthwhile. Embrace the process, and let the beauty of your cultivated space be the reward.
Here are five ways to make maintaining your garden easier:
	1.	Mulching: Apply a layer of mulch to suppress weeds, retain moisture, and regulate soil temperature, reducing the need for frequent maintenance.
	2.	Drip Irrigation: Opt for drip irrigation systems to ensure efficient and targeted watering, saving time compared to manual watering while promoting healthier plants.
	3.	Smart Plant Selection: Choose low-maintenance plants suited to your climate and soil conditions, reducing the need for excessive care and attention.
	4.	Raised Beds: Consider raised beds for better soil drainage and aeration, minimizing weed growth and making it easier to control pests.
	5.	Regular Pruning: Stay proactive with regular pruning to promote plant health, control growth, and prevent the need for extensive cleanup sessions later on.

#garden #gardenlove #gardentips #gardentipsandtricks #gardendesign #gardendesignguys #growformegardening #gardeningtips #gardeningideas #gardeninginspiration

Creating a garden that reflects your personality is so important! We can help inspire you!
Don’t hesitate to make changes, move plants, or even start afresh. Your garden is an extension of yourself, and embracing this freedom adds a personal touch to your outdoor space. Plant what you love in your garden and your garden will be beautiful! 
Here are 5 ways to make your garden uniquely yours:

1. Choose Signature Plants: Opt for plants that resonate with your style or have personal significance. Whether it’s vibrant flowers, unique succulents, or meaningful herbs, your plant selection can make a statement.

2. Personalized Decor: Integrate elements that showcase your personality. This could be handmade garden art, quirky sculptures, or even repurposed furniture. Infusing personal touches adds character.

3. Creative Layouts: Experiment with unconventional garden layouts. Play with pathways, raised beds, or asymmetrical designs. Your garden should flow in a way that feels natural to you.

4. Seasonal Rotation: Keep your garden dynamic by changing elements with the seasons. Swap out flowers, rearrange ornaments, or introduce seasonal themes to keep it fresh and exciting throughout the year.

5. DIY Projects: Engage in do-it-yourself projects to customize your space. Build unique planters, create personalized garden markers, or craft your own seating areas. DIY additions bring a sense of accomplishment and uniqueness to your garden.

😂😂😂 It MIGHT be an addiction! But can you blame us!?😂😂😂 This was one of our favorite small containers of 2023. Follow us for more garden inspo in 2024!

Here are a few reasons why gardening is so awesome:

	1.	Patience Blooms: From seeds to blossoms, it’s a lesson in patience and the beauty of gradual growth.
	2.	Nature’s Haven: Your garden becomes a therapeutic sanctuary, a place to escape and find peace.
	3.	Harvesting Happiness: Homegrown delights bring a sense of accomplishment and joy to your table.
	4.	Seasonal Symphony: Ever-changing landscapes ensure a dynamic, surprise-filled journey throughout the year.
	5.	Mindful Moments: Gardening promotes mindfulness, grounding you in the present and easing life’s worries.
